subject: Productivity
title: Anchoring Bias in Prioritization
description: A quick win: understand Anchoring Bias in Prioritization.

hook.text: Spin a random wheel showing 65. Now guess what percentage of UN countries are African. Most people guess near 65.

buildup.text: Anchoring bias means the first number you see influences all subsequent estimates, even if it's irrelevant.

discovery.text: In prioritization, the first estimate or ranking proposed often anchors all discussion that follows.

twist.text: Whoever speaks first in a meeting sets the anchor. This gives disproportionate power to the most vocal person.

climax.text: Counter anchoring by collecting independent estimates first, then discussing. Silence before consensus.

punchline.text: The first number isn't the right number. It's just the loudest.

quiz.question: How does anchoring bias affect prioritization meetings?
options: The first estimate proposed influences all subsequent discussion
Later estimates are always more accurate
